title: HMS Severn (P282)
text:
HMS "Severn" is a of the <a href="Royal%20Navy">Royal Navy</a>. Named after the <a href="River%20Severn">River Severn</a>, the ship is the first to bear the name in 56 years. She was built by <a href="VT%20Group">Vosper Thornycroft</a> in <a href="Southampton">Southampton</a> to serve primarily as a fishery protection unit within the United Kingdom's waters along with her two <a href="sister%20ship">sister ship</a>s and . All three were commissioned into service in 2003 to replace the five older s. The ship was decommissioned in 2017, but the Government decided to recommission her as part of <a href="Brexit">Brexit</a> preparedness. She returned to service in 2020 and was recommissioned into the Royal Navy on 28 August 2021.
Construction.
"Severn" was built by <a href="VT%20Group">Vosper Thorneycroft Shipbuilding</a> at its shipyard in <a href="Woolston%2C%20Southampton">Woolston, Southampton</a>. Following construction, she was <a href="Ceremonial%20ship%20launching">launched</a> on 4 December 2002 as the second vessel of her <a href="River-class%20offshore%20patrol%20vessel">class</a>. Along with her <a href="sister%20ship">sister ship</a>s, she was among the first vessels to be privately funded by industry and leased to the <a href="Royal%20Navy">Royal Navy</a> for five years. On expiry of this lease, the Royal Navy had the option to either purchase the vessels or return them to VT. On 31 July 2003, "Severn" was <a href="Ship%20commissioning">commissioned</a> into the Royal Navy in a ceremony attended by her Lady Sponsor Professor Felicity Guild in <a href="HMNB%20Portsmouth">Portsmouth</a>.
Operational history.
"Severn" undertook her first fishery protection patrol in September 2003. She was also affiliated with the Welsh city of <a href="Newport%2C%20Wales">Newport</a> during the same month and awarded the <a href="Freedom%20of%20the%20City">Freedom of the City</a> in June 2006.
Between 2005 and 2006, "Severn" spent a total of 225 days at sea on fishery protection duties, her busiest year to date.
In September 2012, "Severn" was purchased by the Royal Navy, along with her sister ships, after their leases had expired.
In October 2014, it was announced that "Severn" would be the first River-class vessel to deploy overseas to take up the <a href="Standing%20Royal%20Navy%20deployments%23Atlantic%20Patrol%20Tasking%20North">Atlantic Patrol Tasking North</a>, a task traditionally assigned to a <a href="frigate">frigate</a> or <a href="destroyer">destroyer</a>. Arriving in the <a href="Caribbean">Caribbean</a>, "Severn" patrolled the waters of each <a href="British%20Overseas%20Territory">British Overseas Territory</a> in the region and was on standby to provide any support, ranging from disaster relief to tackling all forms of illicit trafficking. The ship returned to Portsmouth on 16 July 2015, having visited all of the British Overseas Territories in the region.
In December 2015, acting on intelligence from the British <a href="National%20Crime%20Agency">National Crime Agency</a> and French <a href="Direction%20Nationale%20du%20Renseignement%20et%20des%20Enqu%C3%AAtes%20Douani%C3%A8res">DNRED</a>, the ship intercepted the freighter MV "Carib Palm" off the south coast of the United Kingdom and escorted the ship to <a href="Boulogne-sur-Mer">Boulogne-sur-Mer</a>, France where it was searched by French customs. The search uncovered of <a href="cocaine">cocaine</a> with a street value in excess of £350 million.
In April 2017, "Severn" was detached from fishery protection duties to escort the <a href="Russian%20Navy">Russian Navy</a> "Korolev" through the <a href="English%20Channel">English Channel</a>.
Decommissioning and reactivation.
After making what was presumed to be her final visit to her affiliated town of <a href="Newport%2C%20Wales">Newport, Wales</a>, "Severn" was decommissioned at HMNB Portsmouth on 27 October 2017. In March 2018, six months since decommissioning, the Ministry of Defence announced that £12.7 million had been allocated from the <a href="Brexit">EU Exit Preparedness Fund</a> to preserve "Severn" and her two sister ships, should they be required to control and enforce UK waters and fisheries following the United Kingdom's withdrawal from the <a href="European%20Union">European Union</a>. In November 2018, Defence Secretary, <a href="Gavin%20Williamson">Gavin Williamson</a>, confirmed that "Severn" and her sister ships would be reactivated and "forward operated" from their affiliated ports.
Post-reactivation.
"Severn" underwent a refit in 2019 in preparation for her planned regeneration. Despite plans to forward-operate "Severn" from her affiliated port, the ship remained base ported in Portsmouth as of 4 February 2020. After passing her Operational Sea Training (OST) assessment, "Severn" returned to operations in July 2020, although her re-commissioning ceremony was delayed until August 2021 by the COVID pandemic. One of her first operational taskings since rejoining the fleet saw her shadowing <a href="Russian%20Navy">Russian Navy</a> destroyer , <a href="corvette">corvette</a> <a href="Project%2022160%20patrol%20ship">"Vasily Bykov"</a> and their two support ships as they transited through the English Channel on 9 July 2020.
On 6 May 2021, "Severn" was deployed to <a href="Jersey">Jersey</a> alongside , another River-class OPV, after reports that fishing boats from France would blockade the ferry "Commodore Goodwill" from reaching the island at 6am. This was part of a chain of events sparked by a new fishing licence scheme introduced by the Jersey authorities in alleged contravention of <a href="EU%E2%80%93UK%20Trade%20and%20Cooperation%20Agreement">an agreement between the UK and the EU nations</a> and without consultation with the French authorities.
"Severn" was painted in a <a href="Western%20Approaches">Western Approaches</a> <a href="Ship_camouflage%23Royal_Navy_2">camouflage scheme</a> in time for her recommissioning ceremony alongside <a href="HMS%20Belfast">HMS "Belfast"</a> in the <a href="Pool%20of%20London">Pool of London</a> on 28 August 2021. The historic scheme is a tribute to sailors who fought in the <a href="Battle%20of%20the%20Atlantic">Battle of the Atlantic</a>. She thereafter, in her role as the navigation training ship, conducted a Fleet Navigation Officer course in mid-September, a week-long training cruise for navigation officers of larger warships.
